abstract: Federal officials and senior Wall Street executives offered their first public account on Thursday of the harrowing four days of negotiations.
snippet: Federal officials and senior Wall Street executives offered their first public account on Thursday of the harrowing four days of negotiations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Three weeks after the market crisis that forced the rescue of Bear Stearns, federal officials and senior Wall Street executives offered their first public account on Thursday of the harrowing four days of negotiations that led to a deal to sell the investment bank to JPMorgan Chase.

headline.main: Testimony Offers Details of Bear Stearns Deal
headline.print_headline: Bear Stearns in the Committee Room

abstract: John Coyle, the global head of JPMorgan Chase‘s financial sponsor group, is leaving the company to join private equity firm Permira, according to The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: John Coyle, the global head of JPMorgan Chase‘s financial sponsor group, is leaving the company to join private equity firm Permira, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: JPMorgan’s Coyle Said to Take Post at Permira

abstract: JPMorgan Chase said it bought 11.5 million shares of Bear Stearns on the open market, in an effort to gain enough voting power to essentially guarantee its acquisition of the investment bank.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase said it bought 11.5 million shares of Bear Stearns on the open market, in an effort to gain enough voting power to essentially guarantee its acquisition of the investment bank.

headline.main: JPMorgan Hunts Bear on the Open Market

abstract: Even weeks after a revised deal to sell Bear Stearns was reached, the topic remains the subject of furious speculation. In one of the highest profile inquiries into the JPMorgan Chase/federal government deal, the chief executives of both firms, as well as Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke and New York Federal Reserve Chairman Timothy Geitner appeared before the Senate Banking Committee to face questions.
lead_paragraph: Even weeks after a revised deal to sell Bear Stearns was reached, the topic remains the subject of furious speculation. In one of the highest profile inquiries into the JPMorgan Chase/federal government deal, the chief executives of both firms, as well as Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke and New York Federal Reserve Chairman Timothy Geitner appeared before the Senate Banking Committee to face questions.

headline.main: CNBC Video: The Insiders’ Story of the Bear Stearns Deal
